abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Avian Influenza Control
            and Human Pandemic Preparedness and Response Project for
            Kosovo were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            satisfactory; borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: a global
            template can enable rapid, good project design. Including
            terms of reference for specific tasks and technical
            specifications up front in the Operational Manual (OM) is
            critical so as not to stall implementation of any emergency
            project. As stated in all emergency equipment such as
            protective gear and disinfectants for border points were
            included in the project's OM, which helped to hasten
            procurement and implementation. Projects formulated for a
            specific disease can prove to have too narrow a Project
            Development Objective (PDO) and, therefore, require
            restructuring. The project was formulated specifically to
            address Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI), but some
            of its outputs, such as, enhanced veterinary epidemiology
            unit and intensive care unit, had from the outset wider
            applications to other diseases. Decentralized task
            management for supervision missions can be effective and
            save costs. Utilization of country specialists based in
            neighboring countries for project supervision in Kosovo
            proved successful and represented cost savings when compared
            with the alternative of bringing experts from another
            continent. Close coordination with specialized UN agencies
            can enhance the quality of technical assistance and produce
            cost savings. UN agencies can extend Bank project outreach.
            World Health Organization (WHO) and United Nations
            International Children's Fund (UNICEF) extended
            outreach in Kosovo by assisting the project to access
            communities in ethnic enclaves. The UN agencies had working
            relations with ethnic minority community-based
            organizations, broadcasters and decentralized health centers
            and used these contacts to benefit project implementation.
            Video conferencing can be an effective way to provide
            regular implementation advice between bi-annual supervision
            missions. This is a relatively inexpensive way of
            maintaining a stream of advice and support.
